results.title: Oz shorts. Part 1
results.creator_credit: Catherine Birmingham, Robert Herbert, Roland Gallois, Bernard Purcell, Jo Bell, Sophie Jackson, AFTRS, Arcadia Pictures, Australian Film Commission, NRG Films Australia and Puss Puss Productions,
results.brief_description: A wonderful compilation of Australian short films from the early 1990’s. The films are: “He and She” (Dir: R. Herbert) - a bickering couple get picked up by the police; “Drive” (C. Birmingham) - a mother and son take to the road after killing the “old man”; “Lullabies” (R. Gallois) - a gut-wrenching experimental film on the trauma of a dissolving relationship; “Just Desserts” (M. Pellizzari) - a delicious comedy about an Italo-Australian girl’s sexual awakening and her love for her mama’s cooking; “Excursion to the Bridge of Friendship” (C. Andreef) - a sophisticated Sydney woman decides to invite her folk-singing Bulgarian cousin to Australia. A very funny “silent” film about culture clash.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Catherine Birmingham, Robert Herbert, Roland Gallois, Bernard Purcell, Jo Bell, Sophie Jackson, AFTRS, Arcadia Pictures, Australian Film Commission, NRG Films Australia and Puss Puss Productions,

results.title: Colin Thiele
results.creator_credit: David Perry, Peter Campbell, AFI [au] and Australia Council
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Videos on Australian Writers: archival writers series II”.
Author, poet and biographer, Colin Thiele recalls his childhood in the German migrant community north of the Barossa Valley and his early love of literature. Thiele remembers his student days and his association with movements such as the Angry Penguins. He also discusses the effect on his life and work of his long battle with rheumatoid arthritis and reads a poem about the isolation of pain.

results.title: Rolf Harris' water safety
results.creator_credit: Jessica Skippon and Rolf Harris Video Productions
results.brief_description: A water safety program featuring Rolf Harris and four children, aimed at children up to about twelve years of age. The tape is divided into three sections. 1. Spot the danger (15 mins.) 2. Boating and falling into cold water (17 mins.) 3. Reach throw wade row and rescue breathing (24 mins.)

results.title: Women in the surf (Captioned)
results.brief_description: The first non-fiction feature about Australia’s women of the surf tells the history of women’s surfing in Australia from 1915. It moves through the big board era to the present day, with women coming into a surfing entity in their own right. The video shows the women surf riders surfing their own calendar and tells of their hopes, fears and pleasures as they ride the waves.

results.title: The Teacher and the Computer
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Living with Computers”.
Teacher, Anne McDougall, talks about the introduction of computers into education and the relationship of the teacher and the computer, a paper presented to the Junior World Computer Congress, Melbourne, October 16-18, 1980.

results.title: Camels and the Pitjantjara
results.creator_credit: Roger Sandall, Curtis Levy and Australian Institute of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Studies
results.brief_description: Shows the daily life of nomadic Central Australians of the Pitjantjara tribe who have acquired camels, guns and other modern equipment. Shows the capture of a wild camel and travels in the MacDonnell Range; hunting rabbits and living off the land.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Roger Sandall, Curtis Levy and Australian Institute of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Studies

results.title: Our peninsula
results.brief_description: A personal narrative by Jenny Macaffer about her family’s relationship with the Mornington Peninsula over three generations using photographic images and computer animation. Pipe music performed by the Rats of Tobruk Memorial Highland Band 1984.

results.title: The Bridge
results.material_description: Single channel moving image, colour and audio
results.brief_description:
“The Bridge” is a celebration of a childhood sense of place and belonging to the filmmakers’ birthplace, Warrandyte by video artist John Hipwell. Created to celebrate the artists’ early nexus with the neighbourhood, landscape and ambience of Warrandyte and its surrounds. “The Bridge” over the Yarra River also symbolises the journey from childhood to manhood. The Visaural (video painting with sound scape) is made up of 8 x 30 sec. short films each representing an important particular place central to the artists’ maturation. When played conitnuously and randomly “The Bridge” becomes a metaphor for the filmmakers’ early journey of adventure, discovery and development.
The titles are:
1. Home, Presbyterian Church and The Bridge
2. Gold mines, Petrol Station and The Bridge
3. Research Look Out, Monsalvat and The Bridge
4. Primary School, Folk Art and The Bridge
5. Creek, Yarra River and The Bridge
6. Moonlight Cottage, Potters Cottage and The Bridge
7. War Memorial, Car wrecks and The Bridge
8. Bush fire, North Warrandyte Fire Brigade and The Bridge
Music composed by John B. Hipwell (John Hipwell’s father)
and cinematography and editing by Adis Hondo.
